articles.headline: Judge Disallows Plan by  Detroit to Pay Off Banks
articles.snippet: In a decision that surprised many, a bankruptcy judge said it was “reasonably likely” that Detroit could free itself of costly swap contracts if it sued the two banks holding them.
articles.abstract: In a decision that surprised many, a bankruptcy judge said it was “reasonably likely” that Detroit could free itself of costly swap contracts if it sued the two banks holding them.
articles.lead_paragraph: A federal judge on Thursday rejected a deal that Detroit had negotiated to help it move forward in bankruptcy, but he did offer some hope, saying the city could borrow $120 million it says it urgently needs to provide services to its residents.

articles.headline: In Age of School Shootings, Lockdown Is the New Fire Drill
articles.snippet: At the whiff of a threat, a generation growing up in the shadow of Columbine and Sandy Hook is trained to snap off the lights, lock the doors and take refuge in corners and closets.
articles.abstract: At the whiff of a threat, a generation growing up in the shadow of Columbine and Sandy Hook is trained to snap off the lights, lock the doors and take refuge in corners and closets.
articles.lead_paragraph: The bomb threat was just a hoax, but officials at Hebron High School near Dallas took no chances: School officials called the police and locked down the school this week. Separately, a middle school 2,000 miles away in Washington State went on lockdown after a student brought a toy gun to class.

articles.headline: Window Is Opening for Change in Tax Code
articles.snippet: Enacting a plan that would close tax loopholes and lower rates, while raising needed federal revenue, would not be easy. But recent work by congressional committees raises some tantalizing possibilities.
articles.abstract: Enacting a plan that would close tax loopholes and lower rates, while raising needed federal revenue, would not be easy. But recent work by congressional committees raises some tantalizing possibilities.
articles.lead_paragraph: Could this be the year that a comprehensive tax reform law is passed by Congress and signed by President Obama?

articles.headline: Advocates for Workers Raise the Ire of Business
articles.snippet: Business officials say advocacy groups often demonize companies unfairly and inaccurately, while the groups question why corporations have attacked such fledgling organizations.
articles.abstract: Business officials say advocacy groups often demonize companies unfairly and inaccurately, while the groups question why corporations have attacked such fledgling organizations.
articles.lead_paragraph: As America’s labor unions have lost members and clout, new types of worker advocacy groups have sprouted nationwide, and they have started to get on businesses’ nerves — protesting low wages at Capital Grille restaurants, for instance, and demonstrating outside Austin City Hall in Texas against giving Apple tax breaks.

articles.headline: Reflections by America’s Buddha of Banking
articles.snippet: As he prepares to step down this month, Ben S. Bernanke, the Federal Reserve chairman, discussed the financial crisis and policies adopted by the central bank.
articles.abstract: As he prepares to step down this month, Ben S. Bernanke, the Federal Reserve chairman, discussed the financial crisis and policies adopted by the central bank.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Federal Reserve chairman, Ben S. Bernanke, seemed so calm during the worst hours of the 2008 financial crisis that Timothy F. Geithner, then the Treasury secretary, once described him as a central banking Buddha.

articles.headline: Banks Keep Their Mortgage Litigation Reserves a Secret
articles.snippet: Some investors are upset that banks will not divulge the amount of money set aside, but some banks say they don’t want regulators to know the number lest the authorities increase settlement totals.
articles.abstract: Some investors are upset that banks will not divulge the amount of money set aside, but some banks say they don’t want regulators to know the number lest the authorities increase settlement totals.
articles.lead_paragraph: From JPMorgan Chase’s $13 billion settlement over mortgage securities to lawsuits brought by bondholders, a barrage of litigation has been raining down on Wall Street banks. Yet the banks are not disclosing a number that is crucial for assessing their ability to deal those legal costs. And, curiously, the regulator that has sway over companies’ disclosure practices has not called on the industry to reveal this important figure so that investors can weigh the institutions’ health.

articles.headline: Bumps on a Road to Revival for Yahoo
articles.snippet: Marissa Mayer’s firing of her top lieutenant, Henrique de Castro, was her first public signal that turning around Yahoo would be far more difficult than some had suggested.
articles.abstract: Marissa Mayer’s firing of her top lieutenant, Henrique de Castro, was her first public signal that turning around Yahoo would be far more difficult than some had suggested.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — It looks as if the Google pixie dust isn’t so easy to spread around.
articles.byline: By Vindu Goel and Claire Cain Miller

articles.headline: Breach at Neiman Marcus Went Undetected From July to December
articles.snippet: The company, which disclosed the data theft of customer information late last week, said it did not believe Social Security numbers or birth dates had been compromised.
articles.abstract: The company, which disclosed the data theft of customer information late last week, said it did not believe Social Security numbers or birth dates had been compromised.
articles.lead_paragraph: The computer network at Neiman Marcus was penetrated by hackers as far back as July, and the breach was not fully contained until Sunday, according to people briefed on the investigation.

articles.headline: Blue and Gray Still in Conflict at a Battle Site
articles.snippet: A proposed monument to Union soldiers at Olustee Battlefield Historic State Park has enraged the area’s Confederate descendants.
articles.abstract: A proposed monument to Union soldiers at Olustee Battlefield Historic State Park has enraged the area’s Confederate descendants.
articles.lead_paragraph: OLUSTEE, Fla. — There is an old saying in this state of seesawing sensibilities: The farther north you go, the farther south you get.

articles.headline: Syrian Rebels Say Cease-Fire Deals Prove Deceptive
articles.snippet: Officials from the United States and Russia have urged localized cease-fires to jump-start peace talks, but some rebels have regretted making deals with the state.
articles.abstract: Officials from the United States and Russia have urged localized cease-fires to jump-start peace talks, but some rebels have regretted making deals with the state.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — To the starving residents and rebel fighters in the bitterly contested suburbs of Damascus, the offer from the Syrian government can be tempting enough to overcome their deep mistrust: a cease-fire accompanied by the delivery of food supplies, if they agree to give up their heavy weapons and let state-run news media show the government’s flag flying over their town.

articles.headline: A First Lady at 50, Finding Her Own Path
articles.snippet: In many ways she is the embodiment of the contemporary, urban, well-heeled middle-aged American woman. Except she is also Michelle Obama.
articles.abstract: In many ways she is the embodiment of the contemporary, urban, well-heeled middle-aged American woman. Except she is also Michelle Obama.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — She has perfected a mean forehand, is working on her yoga poses, dishes with girlfriends over brussels sprouts and dirty martinis (one olive) at the Mediterranean hotspot Zaytinya, pushes her two daughters to play two sports — one of her choosing and one of theirs — and said this week that the wonders of modern dermatology, like Botox, are in the realm of possibility for her.

articles.headline: Obama Outlines Calibrated Curbs on Phone Spying
articles.snippet: In a speech that seemed more calculated to reassure audiences at home and abroad than to force radical change, President Obama announced significant changes to the way the government collects and uses telephone records.
articles.abstract: In a speech that seemed more calculated to reassure audiences at home and abroad than to force radical change, President Obama announced significant changes to the way the government collects and uses telephone records.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama, acknowledging that high-tech surveillance poses a threat to civil liberties, announced significant changes on Friday to the way the government collects and uses telephone records, but left in place many other pillars of the nation’s intelligence programs.
articles.byline: By Mark Landler and Charlie Savage
